Actualmente, Martha trabaja como profesora del nivel inicial en el colegio "283 de Ccatcapampa" en la comunidad de Ccatca, donde ella también vive.     

Con  su próximo préstamo, Martha espera recibir $500 USD. Utilizará el dinero del préstamo para hacer sus trámites de su diploma de bachillerato y también para apoyar a su tía que vende tamales de forma ambulatoria. 

Sus anhelos de Martha es terminar la maestría que está estudiando y abrir un jardín en la ciudad del Cusco y también abrir una tienda de venta de juguetes para bebes.
texts.en:
Martha was born in the city of Sicuani, Canchis province, Cusco department. In the past, Cusco was the capital of the Inca Empire and one of the most important cities of the Perú Viceregency. When Martha became of age, she decided she wanted to be a teacher. She studied at Cusco’s prestigious “Santa Rosa” superior pedagogical institute. She is currently teaching elementary school at “283 de Ccatcapampa” school in Ccata, which is where she also lives. Martha expects to receive $500 USD in her next loan. She will use the funds to pay expenses related to her getting her diploma and also to help her aunt who is an itinerant tamale vendor. Martha’s dream is to finish the Master’s degree she’s currently working on and open a kindergarten in Cusco. She also wants to open a toy store for babies.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For diploma expenses.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace M. is from the village of D'ban, Calamba. She is 38 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns a coco logging business. She's able to earn a monthly net income of $183 from selling coco lumber in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for more than five years.   

In 2000, Grace joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Grace is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to invest in rice retailing. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in rice retailing

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn D. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 43 years old. Evelyn is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products and also baking and selling a variety of breads in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Evelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Nguyễn

texts.en:
N. Nguyễn Thị T. (20201020020), a 33 year old woman living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh, is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, N. owns and operates a business venture providing general services to community members. Engaged in this business for over 11 years, she earns approximately 4.200.000 VND a month.

In 2007, N. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Having repaid her previous loan of 6.048.000 VND from SEDA that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is now requesting a new loan of 8.288.000 VND to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be N.'s fourth loan  from SEDA, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of VietN..

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

N. Nguyễn Thị T. (20201020020) là 33 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh .  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học.  Để kiếm sống, N. Sở hữu và thực hiện hoạt động kinh doanh.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ nói chung cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  N. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 11 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, N. kiếm được khoảng 4.200.000 VND một tháng.

Vào 2007, N. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  N. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thêm hàng hóa tồn kho & vốn lưu động.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 8.288.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua vật tư cần thiết để mở rộng dịch vụ được cung cấp.  Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  N. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải thiện/ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.

Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt N.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita Q. is from the village of Balzain west, Tuguegarao City. She is 49 years old. Teresita is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Yun

texts.en:
Mrs. Yun T. is a middle-aged woman whose husband appears in the photo here. Yun T. owns a small store along the road located near the garment factory where she sells food to sewing laborers to earn a living. She is married with two school-aged kids, while her husband is a construction foreman who has a few employees help him to provide his service. 

Yun T.’s husband is running his service well because he is widely known in construction and has skills in public relations which he uses with his customers. However, his income is not very big as his service has recently come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. So, Yun T. requests a loan for her husband to increase his capital which will allow him to improve his profits. Mrs. Yun T. was not available on that day so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To increase the business capital

loans.name: Nghiêm's Group

texts.en:
H.  Nghiêm Thị is a 29-year-old woman living in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh Bắc Ninh.  H.  is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Nghiêm Xá nhóm 09 (Nhóm 09).

H.  is married and has 1 school-aged child.  To making a living, H.  works in the services sector operating a tailoring business.  The main source of income for the business comes from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members.  H. has been engaged in this business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,800,000 VND a month.

In 2007, H.  joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,600,000 VND from SEDA, which was used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital.  She is now requesting a new loan of 7,392,000 VND, which will be used to invest in renovating the business.  This will be H.’s 4th loan from SEDA.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  Mẫn Thị D. is a 24 year-old woman who is requesting a 6,496,000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

2.  Nghiêm Thị Lượng is a 29 year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock. 

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

texts.en:
Hang T. P. is the leader of a 5-member loan group from SEDA. She was born in 1987. She lives in Duong Nhan village, where she grows rice and raises pigs. She has two children who are still young. Her husband is a mechanic, and together they have a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. Hang T. P. would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to help her breed her pigs. This is her first loan from SEDA.

About other borrowers in her group:

Hien T. N. was born in 1981. She raises pigs. She has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND in order to buy food for her pigs.

Thien D. N. was born in 1980. He has three children. He breeds poultry, and would like to borrow  5,014,000 VND in order to buy food for his animals.

loans.name: Bekzhan

texts.en:
Bekzhan A. is 35 years old and lives with his family in the neighborhood of Kyz-Molo village. He has two daughters: four and two years old.  At his country place, Bekzhan is known as a hard-working and energetic person.

Bekzhan was born in a farmworker’s family and, from early childhood helped his parents in farming. Over the years, he inherited the farm and a house near it. Gaining a wide experience in stockmanship, 15 years ago Bekzhan started his business in cattle breeding, which became the main source of income for his family. Due to his strong efforts, Bekzhan has developed his farm and today it amounts to ten milk cows and five bulls. Bekzhan and his wife sell milk to their loyal customers and have earnings of 10,000 Kyrgyz Soms monthly.

Bekzhan plans to use the loan of 90,000 Kyrgyz Soms to broaden his business through buying three milk cows, which will allow for increased milk sales. With the revenues from the loan, he plans to broaden his business by purchasing more cattle.

Bekzhan is doing his best to provide good conditions in which his children can develop. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Ngveang

texts.en:
Mrs. Ngveang T. sells fresh fish in the market to earn a living. Every day in the late morning, she goes to a place where fishermen sell fish in bulk. Then she hurries to bring the fish to the market, where she sells them retail. Ngveang T. has another financial earner in her husband who appears in the photograph here. He works in the construction sector. The couple has two teenage children who work as hairdressers.

Ngveang T. runs her business well because she sells at reasonable prices and has skills in public relations which she uses with her customers. Recently, Ngveang T. received orders for lots of fish from her regular customers, but she lacks the capital to better meet her customers' requirements. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To provide more capital to better meet her customers' requirements.

loans.name: Loep

texts.en:
Mrs. S., 36, is married to Res Minh, age 41, and they have two school-aged kids.

S. combines various types of root trees to create natural medicine to examine people who are her nearby neighbors. This skill she learned from her grandparent, who died of senility years ago. As another source of family income, she has a life partner in her husband, who buys and sells vehicle,. He always buys secondhand motorcycles at cheap prices, and then repairs/paints them for a while before selling them to raise revenue. Because the vehicle selling business is an important source of family income and in order to earn additional income, S. has decided to borrow a loan for her husband to buy more vehicles to resell.

loans.use: To buy more vehicles to resell.

loans.name: Maricris

texts.en:
Maricris C. is from the village of Allinguigan 3rd. She is 38 years old. Maricris is married and has 6 infant children. To make a living, Maricris owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maricris has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maricris joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricris has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,800 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Maricris is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Maricris from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Sip

texts.en:
Sip H. is a 59 year old rice and vegetable grower from Battambang Province. She runs her business on her own farmland, where she grows different kinds of crops like cabbage, rice, and morning glories. She will sell the crops to a buyer when they have matured.

Sip H. is a widowed woman and the mother of three kids. She has another financial earner in her daughter, in the photograph above, who sells a few snack foods to earn a living. Sip H. requests a loan of $600 to be used to buy a used motorcycle to make family transportation easier. She proposes to plant crops by using any remaining cash from the loan.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle.

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhorn Y. (pictured here), is 58 years old and her husband, Mr. Kong Phoung, is 59 years old, and they live along National Road Number One about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1970 and have eight children: five sons and three daughters. Four of them are married and live outside the family home, three are construction workers, and other one is a traditional musician.  

Sokhorn has been a vegetable farmer for seven years. Her husband has been a traditional musician for thirty years. She is asking for her first loan in the amount of 1,000 USD to buy a motorcycle for her children to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to work.

loans.name: Sary

texts.en:
Mr. Sary V. is a driver; he drives for a company in Phnom Penh City. His wife is a garment factory worker. They have been married since 2008, and have no children. The family lives in a village along National Road Number one, approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sary is asking for his first loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work. 

In the photo is Sary’s mother, because he and his wife were at work when the photo was taken.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for commuting to work.

loans.name: Siren

texts.en:
Mrs. Siren K., is 27 years old and her husband, Ms. Sophearak Keo, is 28 years old, and they have been married since 2005. They have two children: one son and one daughter. All of them are still young. They live with their parents about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Siren and her husband are farmers. They grow cauliflowers and beans on their farmland in the village. The family depends on their farming business, which is the main source of income. They do not have enough capital to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain their farm and pay for plowing fees. 

Therefore, Siren is asking for her first loan of $1,000 help her capital. 

In the photo Siren is at home, not on the farm.

loans.use: To use for growing cauliflowers.

loans.name: Reun

texts.en:
Mr. Reun K., 57 (pictured with his wife) and his wife, Mrs. Sokha Long, 56, live in a village along National Road Number one, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1980 and have seven children - four sons and three daughters. Three of them are married and live in separate homes, two are security guards, and the other two are garment factory workers.
 
Reun has been a motor taxi driver since 1990. His wife sells porridge in the village. He is requesting his first loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike for his children to drive to work. He also will use a part of the loan to repair the house where he lives.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for his children to drive to work and repair the house where he lives.

loans.name: Sokhan

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhan K. (pictured here), and her husband, Mr. Thouk Mao, got married in 1994 and now have two daughters. Both of them are in school. They are living on an island in the MeK. River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sokhan is a silk weaver. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a vegetables farmer for more than 22 years.

The family has requested a Kiva loan one time already. Sokhan is now asking for another US$100 to help supply her husband with the capital to purchase fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his vegetable farm, so that he can continue to increase the volume of vegetables.

loans.use: To provide capital for her husband’s farming business.

loans.name: Thach

texts.en:
Mrs. Thach P. (in the photo), is 50 years old and lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh. She is a widow with two sons and three daughters. One of her sons is married and lives outside the family home and the other one attends school. All of her daughters are garment factory workers.

Thach has been selling boiled eggs and grilled beef at her home for more than a year. She has previously taken out a Kiva loan to purchase a motorbike for her daughters to drive to work. She is now applying for another loan of $900 to buy another motorbike for her son to drive to school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her son to drive to school.

loans.name: Bunnet

texts.en: Mr. Bunnet M. (not in the photo; his wife is pictured instead) and his wife, Mrs. Sreytoch Thoeun, have been married since 1998 and have four children. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Bunnet has full-time employment in Phnom Penh. His wife weaves silk at home and takes care of their children. Bunnet is requesting a loan of $550 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Mrs. Van P. currently cultivates various crops to earn a living. She is 52 years old and a resident of Battambang province, located about 280 km from the capital, Phnom Penh. She is a single mother, with seven children who are all single. Van P. also relies on the income from her daughter who mends and sews clothes in the village. Van P. wishes to have more income to ensure that her family can meet their current expenses with more stability. To achieve her goal, Van P. would like to invest in a new business of buying and selling mature rice in bulk, but she is concerned that she doesn’t have enough money yet to begin the process. Therefore, Van P. is humbly requesting a loan in order to buy 2000 kg of rice to store for a while before selling it at a profit. Mrs. Van P. was not available when the photograph was taken, so her daughter is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy 2000 kg of rice for resale.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia L. is from the village of Poblacion, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 47 years old. Virginia is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Virginia owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products like special macaroni salad in a plastic container in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Virginia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand the business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Haki Sawa Group

texts.en:
Zuhura Abdallah, age 33, is single and has two children ages 8 and 15 years.  She has operated a café business for 2 years now.  She works from 7am to 4 pm daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $129.

This will be Zuhura second motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended.  She used the previous motisha loan to increase on her business stock and she has paid back the loan successfully. She hopes for a new motisha loan to buy more items for her café such as utensils, chairs, rice and flour.   She hopes that her business continues to improve and grow, so that she can continue to help her family.  

Zuhura will share this loan with her loan group, Haki Sawa, which has 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.
In the picture, Zuhura is the woman wearing the plaid kilemba (hair wrap) with a white t-shirt, sitting in the front row.

loans.use: To buy utensils, chairs, flour and rice for cafe.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom S. A. is a married mother caring for two kids. Both of them attend the local school and are dependent on her income. Her husband is a professional teacher who teaches the secondary class. 

To earn a living, Mom S. A. sells fish paste that she buys in bulk from her supplier. She also buys fresh fish and turns them into fish paste.

Mom S. A. is concerned that her current business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. She wishes to have more money to increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan. (Mrs. Mom S.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To increase her capital

loans.name: Gombo

texts.en:
Gombo A. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Uvs province, western Mongolia, in their own ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. The elder son is a student, while the other children attend a local middle school.

Gombo began his business in 2000 with the help of his wife. They sew a variety of shoes and clothing including deels, traditional Mongolian garments, and other coats that are suitable for the spring and fall weather in Mongolia. Since managing their business successfully, Gombo and his wife have been able to afford their children's tuition fees.

Gombo also makes hay from two hectares (five acres) of land once a year and sells the hay in autumn. He is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to use for cutting the hay.

loans.use: To cut hay

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en: Zenaida C. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 47 years old and is married with five school-aged children. Zenaida owns and operates a business raising cultured vermi-worms (worms used to compost organic waste) to produce fertilizers. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Zenaida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vermi-worms to raise. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additonal vermi-worms to raise

loans.name: Rodelisa

texts.en: Rodelisa R. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 24 years old and is married with three infant children. Rodelisa owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling lumber and wood-related products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Rodelisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. loans.name: Classic Group

texts.en:
Fedrick Mikael, age 37, is married with four children aged 15, 14, 13 and 9 years. In the picture, Fedrick is sitting in the front row, first on the right wearing a white shirt.

Fedrick has been selling food items at his shop for two years now. He works from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. and is able to make a monthly profit of about $129.

This will be Fedrick’s second motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended.

Fedrick used his previous motisha loan to improve his shop and he has managed to pay back the loan successfully. He hopes for a new motisha loan to buy more food items such as salt, sugar, flour and rice. His dream is to buy more products to increase the stock in his shop.

Fedrick will share this loan with his loan group, Classic, which totals eight members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To buy more food items such as salt, sugar, flour and rice for his shop

loans.name: Baatarjav

texts.en:
Baatarjav D. is 48 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvs province, western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son was demobilized from the army this year and his daughter is a student in a university.

Baatarjav operates a shoemaking business in his town and his wife helps him with sewing the shoes. He sews many types of shoes including the traditional Mongolian shoes which are well known as “a pair of white-soled shoes” which are popular and warm and valued by his customers for their quality and design.

Baatarjav began this business in 1990 and since then he has gained a lot of experience and knows what his customers want and how much they are willing to pay for his quality shoes. He sells his products to stock keepers through trade fairs or by wholesale. The business has been so successful that he purchased a car which allows him to deliver his products to his customers.

Baatarjav is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more fabrics and finishing materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics and finishing materials for his business

loans.name: Math

texts.en:
Math F. is a young woman whose husband appears in the photograph. Math F. lives with another family member in the capital of Phnom Penh. She has rented a market store, where she sells chickens to earn a living. She and her husband usually go to buy chicken in bulk at the cheapest price possible from rural people whose houses are full of the poultry they raise. 

Math F.'s business has recently come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. Math F. would like to seek a loan on Kiva through HKL’s project. She will be using her loan to increase her capital, which will allow her to improve her profits.

loans.use: To increase her capital

loans.name: Luvisminda's Group

texts.en:
Luvisminda G. is from the village of San Bernardo. She is 58 years old. Luvisminda is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Luvisminda G.'.

Luvisminda is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Luvisminda owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Luvisminda has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Luvisminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luvisminda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Luvisminda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Erdenebileg

texts.en:
Erdenebileg B. is 40 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Uvs province, western Mongolia. He and his family have been living together in a house for 9 years. Erdenebileg began his carpentry business in 2003. He produces  'ger'--a traditional Mongolian housing tent--parts such as wooden walls, doors and poles, which make up a 'ger' roof while his wife sews shoes which are well-known as “a pair of white-soled shoes,”  popular and warm. 

Erdenebileg and his wife are working hard to expand their product line to include furniture as well. Erdenebileg would one day like to open a small factory in which he can produce even more products with ease.  He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more wood, fabrics, finishing materials and supplies in order to expand his business and keep up with customers’ orders.

loans.use: To  purchase materials for his and his wife's businesses

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhun R. is an older woman and is the mother of three teenage children. She is a good housewife who arranges a daily routine and takes care of the kids. The family's livelihood is contributed to by Chhun R.’s husband who works in the MinistR. of the Interior. Another source of family income comes from Chhun R.’s daughter who works as a waitress in a restaurant located in the middle of Phnom Penh city. 

Chhun R. is taking out her first loan to repair/decorate her old house, where she plans to operate a small business in the future. (Mrs. Chhun R.’s daughter is pictured.)

loans.use: To repair/re-decorate her old house, where she plans to operate a small business in the future

loans.name: Lilibeth's Group

texts.en:
Lilibeth L. is from the village of Padul, Solana, Cagayan. She is 47 years old. Lilibeth is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lilibeth is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Lilibeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Lilibeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Bekkul

texts.en:
Bekkul A. was born into a family of farm workers, where cattle-breeding was passed on from one generation to another. From early childhood, he helped his parents in farming and animal breeding. After graduating from secondary school and serving in the army, he returned home and got a job at a local farm.

Later, after marrying and becoming a father of three children, Bekkul decided to start his own business in cattle breeding. Using his starting capital of 3,000 Kyrgyz Soms, he bought one milk cow and, owing to a persistent and hardworking personality, managed to multiply his investments. Presently, his farm has 3 milk cows, 20 sheep and 2 bulls. Last year, Bekkul applied for a loan to buy cattle and repaid it without any delays.

Bekkul plans to use this loan of 65,000 Kyrgyz Soms to increase his number of cattle for fattening and reselling, and in the future he plans to buy a car for his elder son and hold his wedding.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose P., from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon, is 34 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Rose owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over a year, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Rose joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan for 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Engaged in her business for over six years, she earns approximately 4200 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jesusa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP for the same purpose. This will be Jesusa's fourth loan from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Cheth

texts.en:
Cheth M. is 45 years of age and a married woman. In order to meet the needs of her family, Cheth M. sells some supplies for students inside a local school located near her house. She has had experience in this sector for nine years and is earning approximately $6 per day.

To help contribute to her family, her husband works as a teacher in the secondary school (he appears in the photo). This couple have been married for years and they have four children, three of whom are now married and the other is single.

In order to reduce her transportation costs, Cheth M. is applying for a loan to buy a used motorbike that she will use to either transport her inventory or to travel anywhere.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike.

loans.name: Estela

texts.en: Estela P. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 33 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Estela owns and operates a transportation service using a motorela (a motorcycle encased in a carriage with two rows of seats facing each other), with her husband as the driver, for local community members. Estela has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Estela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estela is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide her service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Estela from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. In 2010, Annie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annie is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Annie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Kapamba Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth M., age 35, is single with two children who are 13 and 16 years old.  She has operated a beauty salon and a cafe for three years now.  She works from 7 am to 10 pm daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $200.

This will be Elizabeth’s first motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  A motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has end. She hopes for a new motisha loan to buy supplies for her salon and her café.  Her dream is to buy a more hair dryers and steamers and continue widening her café to become international.

Elizabeth will share this loan with her loan group, Kapampa, which has seven members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Elizabeth is in the center wearing a colored blouse.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her salon and cafe.

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames, les dix membres du groupe Benkadi 1 de Bènèbougou ont en moyenne 41 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Bènèbougou dans la commune rurale de Pelengana dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Des spéculations comme le mil, le fonio et le niébé seront cultivées par les membres du groupe.
Madame Sitan Dembélé compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 3 sacs de complexe céréale, 4 dabas et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage  dans ses champs. Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles au grand marché de Ségou, en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes et des femmes du village. 
Elle compte produire 10 sacs de mil, 6 sacs de fonio, 2 sacs de niébé et faire des bottes avec des fanes de niébé sur sa surface de culture de 3 hectares. Une partie de la production est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu avec les bottes pour prendre en charge les soins de santé et les frais de scolarisation des enfants. 
Madame Sitan   Dembélé à l’image des autres femmes du groupe a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le village.
texts.en:
Predominantly married into polygamous families, the ten members of the group Benkadi 1 of Bènèbougou are 41 years old and have 3 children, on average. They all live in the village of Bènèbougou in the rural commune of Pelengana in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali). They know one another through their marital, parentage and neighborhood ties. With the goal of increasing their cultivable land, they appealed to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 2nd farm loan. Crops like millet, fonio (a species of millet from Mali), and black-eyed peas will be cultivated by the members of the group. Mrs. Sitan Dembélé expects to use her loan to buy 3 bags of complex fertilizer and 4 axes, and to recruit the manual labor needed for the labor and hoeing activities in the fields. She gets fresh agricultural supplies at the big market in Ségou, and the manual labor from the association of young people and women in the village. She expects to produce 10 bags of millet, 6 bags of fonio, 2 bags of black-eyed peas and to make boots with the tops of the black-eyed pea plants from her 3 hectare cultivable area. She will use a part of what is produced herself, while the rest will be sold with the boots to care for the health needs and schooling costs of her children. Mrs. Sitan Dembélé, like the other women of the group, also wants to assure the village's self-sufficiency in providing food.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers (complex fertilizers), small tools (axes), and to hire manual labor

loans.name: Din

texts.en: Mr. Din M., 36, is a village man living in Kompong Tom Province. He is a local crop farmer growing rice, vegetables, and some fruit on his own farmland. He was married and has three children who live together in the family home. To facilitate the work on the farm, his wife works in the farm fields frequently alongside him. Growing crops is an annual action with which the couple has had great success. They are able to plant the crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. Din M. is looking for a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, and seeds for planting.

loans.use: To use towards purchasing fertilizers, insecticides, and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Djamadjigui 1 Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygamiques, les six membres du groupe Djamadjigui 1 ont en moyenne 42 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent b toutes dans le village de Moudjirila dans la commune urbaine de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies à cultiver, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Le mil, le fonio, l’arachide et le riz seront cultivés par les membres du groupe.
Madame Alimata   Traoré compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 3 sacs de complexe céréale, 25kg de semence d’arachide, 3 bidons d’herbicide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage  dans ses champs. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles au grand marché de Ségou, en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes et des femmes du village. 
Elle compte produire 15 sacs d’arachide et 10 sacs de mil avec sa superficie de culture de 2 hectares. Une partie de la production est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu afin de prendre en charge les soins de santé des enfants et des condiments du foyer. 
Madame Alimata   Traoré espère réaliser 75.000FCFA en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The six members of the Djamadjigui 1 group, married and living for the most part in large polygamous families, are on the average 42 years of age and have 4 children. They all live in the village of Moudjirila in the township of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mali) and know each other as relatives by blood or marriage or as neighbors. In order increase their workable land, they have turned to Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second agricultural loan. The group members will cultivate millet, fonio [ a millet species common to West Africa], peanuts and rice. Mrs. Alimata Traoré plans to use her loan to purchase 3 bags of complex fertilizers, 25 kg [55 lbs] of peanut seed, 3 cans of herbicide and to recruit manual laborers for working and weeding the fields. She purchases agricultural inputs at the big market of Ségou and recruits laborers through the local young people’s association and the women’s association. She plans to produce 15 bags of peanuts and 10 bags of millet on her land plot of 2 hectares [about 5 acres]. Part of the produce will be consumed by the family, and the remainder will be sold to provide for the children’s healthcare expenses and household condiments. At the end of the season, Mrs. Alimata Traoré hopes to earn 75,000 West African Francs.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing complex fertilizers, peanut seed & herbicides and paying for manual labor

loans.name: Asgar

texts.en: Asgar Q. is a 32 year old farmer who breeds sheep and cows in the small village of Saatli. He has five years of experience in this field. Asgar  is married and has two children. He sells sheep to the local café owners and to butchers. He uses cows to produce milk products for his family. Now he would like to expand his business and to purchase more sheep and one milking cow to sell milk and milk products to the local people and stores. For this purpose he applied for 900 AZN.

loans.use: To purchase four sheep and one milking cow.

loans.name: Nazli

texts.en: Nazli S. is a 45 year old woman who has been engaged in farming and cattle breeding for the past 10 years. She is married and has three children. She and her husband produce seasonal fruits and vegetables and at the same time buy small cattle, fatten them, raise and sell them in the livestock bazaar. Nazli applied for 1000 AZN in order to purchase more cattle as this is the main financial source for her family.

loans.use: To purchase two cattle.

loans.name: Feride

texts.en: Feride N.  is a 55 year old woman who breeds cattle in the small village of Saatli. She is married and has three children. Feride applied for 1000 AZN in order to purchase more cattle and sheep. Her primary customers are local butchers. Once a month her husband takes animals for sale to the livestock bazaar. Feride wishes to improve her life conditions and to increase her income with this loan.

loans.use: To purchase four sheep and one cow.

loans.name: Pat

texts.en: Mrs. Pat H. is a 43-year-old farmer and mother. She was blessed with six children, two of whom are married and the other four are single. To help with the responsibility for family expenses, three of her daughters are employed in the garment factory. Pat H. has another financial earner in her husband who is a skilled producer of handmade wooden beds, from which he earns a living. Recently, Pat H.’s husband got many orders for beds from his customers but he lacks items to meet this orders. Therefore, Pat H. decided to ask for a Kiva loan for her husband to use to buy raw materials to make additional beds for his customers.

loans.use: To buy raw materials to make additional beds for his customers.

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en: Susanna P. lives in Hatsavan village of Syunik marz in Armenia. Together, with her husband and two children, Susanna and her family are occupied in breeding cattle and in land cultivation. Susanna is a very enthusiastic woman willing to improve her family’s condition. This loan will help her buy some livestock.

loans.use: For buying livestock.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David C. is a 30 year old married father of two children. He has a wife who is 28 years old and is a housewife.
David runs a barter trade business popularly known as 'mali kwa mali' in swahili. His business has been in operation for the last seven years.

This marks David's first borrowing from KADET and with the money he plans to purchase business goods for his businesses i.e washing basins and utensils. His major customers include the local passersby and retailers.

In the future David hopes to become a successful businessman.

loans.use: To purchase business goods for his businesses i.e washing basins and utensils.

loans.name: Djamadjigui 2 Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygamiques, les six  membres du groupe Djamadjigui 2 ont en moyenne 40 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Moudjirila dans la commune urbaine de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de cultures, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Le mil, le fonio, l’arachide et le riz sont  les spéculations cultivées par les membres du groupe.
Madame Mariam  Traoré compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 2 sacs de complexe céréale, 20kg de semence d’arachide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles au grand marché de Ségou, en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes et des femmes du village. Elle espère produire 13 sacs d’arachide, 6sacs de mil et 3sacs de fonio avec sa superficie de culture de 1,50    hectare. 
La production du mil et du fonio est auto consommée tandis que celle d’arachide est vendue pour la prise en charge des soins de santé des enfants, des denrées alimentaires et des cas sociaux. 
Madame Mariam  Traoré tout comme les autres femmes du groupe a pour objectif de faire l’élevage des petits ruminants qui par la suite peut lui permettre d’avoir ses propres bœufs de labour.
texts.en:
Predominantly married into large polygamous families, the six members of the group Djamadjigui 2 are on average 40 years old and have 3 children. They all live in the village of Moudjirila in the urban community of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali) and know one another through marital and parental ties. With the goal of increasing their cultivable land, they appealed to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second farm loan. Millet, fonio (a millet grown in Mali), peanuts and rice are the crops cultivated by the members of the group. Mrs. Mariam Traoré expects to use her loan to buy 2 bags of complex fertilizer, 20 kg of peanut seeds and to recruit the manual labor for the labor and hoeing activities in the fields. She gets her supply of agricultural inputs at the large market in Ségou, and her manual labor from the association of young people and women of the village. She hopes to produce 13 bags of peanuts, 6 bags of millet and 3 bags of fonio on her 1.5 hectares of cultivable land. The millet and fonio she produces she consumes herself, while the peanuts produced are sold to pay for the health needs of her children, perishable foods and social cases. Mrs. Mariam Traoré, like all the other women of the group, has the objective of raising small ruminant animals, which will eventually allow them to have their own steer for labor.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers (complex fertilizers), peanut seeds, and to use manual labor for labor and hoeing.

loans.name: Tuyet

texts.en: Tuyet T. Dinh was born in 1974. She has four children (two sons and two daughters). She breeds poultry (about 60 chickens). Her husband is a carpenter. He earns a monthly income. Her family has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2006 and repaid punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND in order to breed poultry.

loans.use: To breed poultry

loans.name: Kheav

texts.en: Mr. Kheav R. is 43 years old, married and devoted to his five children who are students in the local public school. In his time away from school, one of his sons is a fisherman. Kheav R. is a local merchant who sells salt and vegetables in bulk door-to-door around his community. Another source of his income is from working with his wife to grow mushrooms on their own farmland located next to their house. Kheav R. owns other village land, on which he has been planning to build a new house for his child to live in but his goal does not come true because he is lacking funds. To achieve his goal, Kheav R. has decided to seek a loan for $1,100 to add to his savings in order to construct a new house. Mr. Kheav R. was busy at his business, so his wife was photographed instead.

loans.use: To construct a new house.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela O. is a hardworking lady based in Kisumu, a lakeside city in Western Kenya along Lake Victoria. She is married to Agripa Onguka, a college teacher. They have three children between 8 and 16 years old. 

Pamela operates a salon and boutique at the town center in Kisumu city where she sells new clothes and salon materials like weaves, pieces for hair plaiting and many more beauty products. From this business, Pamela makes a monthly income of around Kshs. 33,400 ($417).Confidently, Pamela has operated this business for the last 13 years and therefore she has wide experience. She is taking her fourth loan from Kadet Limited and she is confident that she will be able to pay in full without default. She intends to use the loan to buy weaves, new clothes and pieces for plaiting. 

From the anticipated profits, Pamela will ensure she uses it to educate her children and ensure that their living standards improve for the better. Apart from this, she has plans to open other businesses and her plan at the moment is to open the popular money transfer business service (locally known as M-pesa). For sure, the sky is the limit for Pamela. She hopes to get a Kiva lender to help her realize these plans.

loans.use: To buy new clothes and pieces for hair plaiting.

loans.name: Tièssiri 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe Tièssiri 1 sont mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygames, avec en moyenne 34 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Siradjankoro dans la commune rurale de Pelengana dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d'augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1ier  cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver le mil, l’arachide et le fonio.
Madame Fatoumata  Traoré compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 25kg de semences d’arachide,  un sac de complexe céréale et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de récolte  pour son champ d’arachide. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricole à la foire Cinzana Gare et en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes et des femmes du village. 
Avec une superficie de 2,50 hectares, Madame Fatoumata   Traoré espère produire 18 sacs d’arachide et 8 sacs de mil. 
Toute la production du mil serait auto consommée tandis que celle d’arachide sera vendue pour satisfaire les besoins du foyer en condiments et soins de santé des enfants. 
Madame Fatoumata Traoré à l’image des autres femmes du groupe Tièssiri a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le village et faire de l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The eight women of the group Tièssiri 1 are predominantly married into large polygamous families, are on average 34 years old and have 5 children. They all live in the village of Siradjankoro in the rural community of Pelengana in the region of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali) and know one another through marital, parental and neighborhood ties. With the goal of increasing their cultivable lands, they appealed to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 1st farm loan. The members of the group are going to cultivate millet, peanuts and fonio (a type of millet produced in Mali). Mrs. Fatoumata Traoré expects to use her loan to buy 25 kg of peanut seeds, a bag of complex fertilizers, and to recruit the manual labor for the labor and harvesting for the peanut fields. She refreshes her supply of agricultural inputs at the fair in Cinzana Gare and gets her manual labor from an association of young people and women from the village. With 2.5 hectares of land, Mrs. Fatoumata Traoré hopes to produce 18 bags of peanuts and 8 bags of millet. She will consume all the millet she produces, while the peanuts she produces will be sold to satisfy the household needs in condiments and to care for the health of her children. Mrs. Fatoumata Traoré, like the other women of the Tièssiri group, has as her objective the dietary self-sufficiency of the village and to raise small ruminant animals.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanut seeds, complex fertilizer, and to use manual labor for the labor and harvesting

loans.name: Cay

texts.en: Cay T. T. was born in 1956. She not only grows rice but she breeds 200 chickens too. She has two children who are married. Her husband is a carpenter. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2006 and repaid punctually. For this loan, she would like to borrow 5,450,000 VND to buy food for her chickens.

loans.use: To buy food for her chickens

loans.name: Tièssiri 2 Group

texts.fr:
Mariés majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygamiques, les sept  membres du groupe Tièssiri 2 ont en moyenne 29 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans le village de Siradjankoro dans la commune rurale de Pelengana dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d'augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1ier  cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver le mil, l’arachide, le sésame et le fonio.
Madame Minata Traoré compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 25kg de semences d’arachide, recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour, de désherbage et de récolte  dans ses différentes parcelles de culture. 
Elle se ravitaille en semences agricoles à la foire Cinzana Gare et en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes et des femmes du village. 
Avec une superficie de 1,50hectare, Madame Minata Traoré compte produire 20 sacs d’arachide et 7 sacs de fonio. 
Une partie de la production du fonio et d’arachide est auto consommée dans la famille ordinairement ou utilisée lors des cérémonies de mariage, baptême ou funérailles alors que le reste sera vendu pour satisfaire les besoins du foyer en condiments, soins de santé des enfants et autres. 
Madame Minata Traoré à l’image des autres femmes  a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le village.
texts.en:
Predominantly married in large polygamous families, the seven members of the group Tièssiri 2 are on average 29 years old, have 2 children and all live in the village of Siradjankoro in the rural commune of Pelengana in the region of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali). They know one another through marital, neighborhood and parental ties. With the goal of increasing their cultivable land, they appealed to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 1st farm loan. The members of the group are going to cultivate millet, peanuts, sesame and fonio (a type of millet produced in Mali). Mrs. Minata Traoré expects to use her loan to buy 25 kg of peanut seeds and to recruit the manual labor for the labor, weeding, and harvesting in the different cultivated plots of land. She refreshes her supply of agricultural seeds at the fair in Cinzana Gare and gets her manual labor from an association of young people and women from the village. With 1.5 hectares of land, Mrs. Minata Traoré expects to produce 20 bags of peanuts and 7 bags of fonio. A part of the fonio and peanuts produced is ordinarily consumed by the family itself or used during marriage ceremonies, baptism and funerals, while the rest will be sold to meet the needs of the household in condiments, the cares of their children's house, and other things. Mrs. Minata Traoré like the other women of the group, has the objective of dietary self-sufficiency in the village.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanut seeds and to use manual labor for laboring, hoeing and harvesting.

loans.name: Djeneba

texts.fr:
Madame Djeneba C. est âgée de 47 ans, divorcée  et mère  de 2 enfants. Elle vit chez elle même  dans une famille nucléaire au  quartier Médine  de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Secrétaire à la douane de Ségou, parallèlement à cette activité, Djeneba mène des activités génératrices de revenus, notamment  le commerce de jus, qu’elle pratique depuis 35 ans. Elle a commencé auprès de sa mère qui vendait des jus lors des recréations aux abords des écoles fondamentales. Sa force de vente est due à la qualité de son jus, bien préparé et très bien conservé.   
Pour faire son jus elle utilise 5 kilogrammes de sucre, 1kilogramme de gingembre, 2 kilogrammes de Tomi, 20 sachet de sucre vanilles et 4 sachets de poudre de jus (banane,  mangue et orange). Le tout est mélangé dans 1litre et ½  d’eau  afin d’avoir le goût recherché,  le breuvage  mis  dans des bidons soigneusement lavés seront dans le réfrigérateur pour refroidissement
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfice. Elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 12 mois. Après  1 prêt individuel correctement bien remboursé, elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter 1 congélateur.  Elle s’approvisionne sur place.
Madame Djeneba C. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permet de subvenir à ses propres besoins et de participer aux événements sociaux (baptême, mariage etc.…).
texts.en:
Mrs. Djeneba C. is 47 years old, divorced and the mother of two children. She lives with her nuclear family in the Médine district of Segou (the third administrative district of Mali). She is a secretary at the Ségou Customs office; parallel to that work, she also earns money through other business activities, mainly selling juice, which she has been doing for 35 years. She learned this trade from her mother, who used to sell juice by primary schools during recess. Her strong side is the high quality of her juice, well prepared and carefully conserved. II order to make her jjuice, she uses 5 kg [11 lbs] of sugar, 1 kg [2.2. lbs] of ginger, 2 kg [4.8 lbs] of tamarind, 20 packs of vanilla and 4 packs of powdered juice (banana, mango and orange). All ingredients are mixed in with 1.5 liter [about 1.6 qt] of water in order to achieve the desired taste. The beverage is then poured into cans which had been carefully washed and placed in the refrigerator to chill. In order to increase her working capital and earn a higher revenue, Mrs. C. has turned to Soro Yiriwaso. She has been a member for 12 months. After duly repaying her first individual loan, she is seeking a second loan in order to purchase a freezer. She stocks up locally. Mrs. Djeneba C. sells for cash and in credit to a customer base composed of both women and men. With this loan, she hopes to achieve a monthly income of 150,000 West African Francs. This will allow her to support herself and to take part in social event such as baptisms, weddings etc.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a freezer

loans.name: Nyètaa 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les sept  femmes du groupe Nyètaa 1 sont toutes mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 41 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Balamissala dans la commune rurale de Sébougou dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne. Le riz, le fonio et le gombo seront cultivés par les membres du groupe.
Madame Korotoumou  C. veut utiliser son prêt  pour acheter 25kg de semences de riz,  deux sacs de complexe céréale, 2 bidons d’herbicide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour, de repiquage et de sarclage dans ses champs. Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles à la foire de Sébougou, en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes et des femmes du village. 
Avec une superficie de 3,1 hectares, elle espère produire 10 sacs de riz, 2 sacs de fonio et une trentaine de sac de gombo. Une partie de la production est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu pour prendre en charge les besoins du foyer en condiments, fournitures scolaires et soins de santé des enfants. Madame Korotoumou  C. à l’image des autres femmes du groupe Nyètaa 1 a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le village et faire de l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The seven women of the Nyètaa 1 group are all married and living in big traditional families. Their average age is 41 and on average they have 4 children each. They live in the village of Balamissala, in the rural community of Sébougou, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of Mali), and they became acquainted because they are either in-laws, neighbors, or related to each other. Wishing to expand their arable land, they came to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second agricultural (seasonal) loan. Members of the group grow rice, "fonio" (a type of millet) and okra. Mrs. Korotoumou C. wants to use her loan to buy 25 kg of rice seed, two sacks of fertilizer for grains, two tins of herbicide, and pay for labor to help her transplant the rice seedings and do the weeding in her fields. She buys her agricultural inputs at the weekly market in Sébougou and finds her laborers among the young people's association and the women of the village. With 3.1 hectares, she hopes to produce 10 sacks of rice, 2 sacks of "fonio", and about 30 sacks of okra. Part of her production will be consumed by her family, whereas the rest will be sold to have money for household needs: condiments, school supplies, and health care for her children. Mrs. Korotoumou C., like the other women of the Nyètaa 1 group, aims to make the village self-sustaining in terms of food and be able to raise goats and sheep.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying fertilizer for grains, rice seeds, herbicides, and paying for labor

loans.name: Nyètaa 2 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Nyètaa 2 est composé de six femmes toutes mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 33 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Balamissala dans la commune rurale de Sébougou dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne. Le riz, l’arachide, le mil et le gombo seront cultivés par les membres du groupe Nyètaa 2 du village de Balamissala.
Madame Mariétou  D. veut utiliser son prêt  pour acheter 30kg de semences de riz,  deux sacs de complexe céréale, 2 bidons d’herbicide et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour, de repiquage et de sarclage dans ses champs. Le labour est réservé aux hommes alors que le sarclage et le repiquage sont l’œuvre des femmes dans le village. Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles à la foire de Ségou (au grand marché). 
Avec une superficie de 3 hectares, elle espère produire 8 sacs d’arachide, 10 sacs de riz et une trentaine de sac de gombo. Une partie de la production est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu pour prendre en charge les frais scolaires des enfants, les besoins du foyer ainsi que les soins de santé. 
Madame Mariétou  D. a pour objectif de faire l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The Nyètaa 2 group is composed of six women, all married and living in big traditional families. Their average age is 33 and on average they have 3 children each. They live in the village of Balamissala, in the rural community of Sébougou, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of Mali), and they became acquainted because they are either in-laws, neighbors, or related to each other. Wishing to expand their arable land, they came to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second agricultural (seasonal) loan. Members of the Nyètaa 2 group from the village of Balamissala grow rice, peanuts, millet, and okra. Mrs. Mariétou D. wants to use her loan to buy 30 kg of rice seed, two sacks of fertilizer for grains, two tins of herbicide, and pay for labor to help her prepare the soil, transplant the rice seedings, and do the weeding in her fields. Preparing the soil is work reserved for men, whereas weeding and transplanting are work done by women from the village. She buys her agricultural inputs at the weekly market in Ségou (the big market). With 3 hectares, she hopes to produce 8 sacks of peanuts, 10 sacks of rice, and about 30 sacks of okra. Part of her production will be consumed by her family, whereas the rest will be sold to have money for the children's school fees, household necessities, and health care expenses. Mrs. Mariétou D. aims to be able to raise goats and sheep.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying fertilizer (a mixture for grains), rice seeds, herbicides, and paying for labor

loans.name: Bintou

texts.fr:
Madame  Bintou Koussoubé est âgée de 44 ans, mariée  et mère  de 6 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son feu mari avec sa coépouse  dans une grande famille traditionnelle au quartier Pelengana Sébénikoro de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fait l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença tôt le petit commerce auprès de sa mère, qui vendait des condiments alimentaires au marché. Après plusieurs années d’activités passé auprès de cette dernière, elle évolua seule en menant le commerce d’articles divers  tels le vente de pâte d’arachide, de légumes, d’habits etc. 
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant  36 mois. Après 2 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels  tous correctement remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, une balle de tissus. 
Elle s’approvisionne sur place à la COMATEX (Compagnie Malienne des Textiles).
Madame Bintou Koussoubé vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de subvenir aux besoins de la famille surtout qu’elle est veuve et ses enfants sont des scolaires. 
Son ambition est de pérenniser son commerce jusqu’à ce que ses enfants puissent avoir la force de prendre en charge les dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Mrs. Bintou Koussoubé, 44, is married and the mother of 6 children. She lives in the home of her late husband with her co-spouse, in a big traditional family in the Pelengana Sébénikoro district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having attended school for socio-economic reasons, she began early on to do petty trading together with her mother, who sold condiments at the market. After several years spent working with her mother, she began to work alone, selling various items such as peanut butter, vegetables, cloth, etc. Wishing to grow her working capital so that she could make more profit, she came to Soro Yiriwaso 36 months ago. With two solidarity loans and two individual loans under her belt, all correctly reimbursed, she is on her third individual loan which she intends to use to buy a bale of cloth. She buys her supplies near where she sells, at COMATEX, Compagnie Malienne des Textiles (Mali Textile Company). Mrs. Bintou Koussoubé sells for cash and credit to a clientele composed of women and men.
