loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel M. is from the village of Mialem, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is 34 years old and is married. Joel owns and operates a business providing mechanical services like motor repair to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over a year and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Joel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in his business. This loan will be his first from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Jasmine

texts.en:
Jasmine B. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Jasmine owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish such as "malansi", "bolinao", "sigarilyo" and more in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Jasmine joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Jasmine is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Jakelyn's Group

texts.en:
Jakelyn T. is from the town of Silanga, Tangub City. She is 31 years old and is the group leader of this seven-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Jakelyn is married and has two school-aged children. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Jakelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. texts.en:
Bella E., age 40, is working hard to cover daily expenses and pay for her children's education. She and her husband, Leonardo, age 52, grow pineapples and raise hogs on their small farm, while also generating income from an apartment they rent out. A recent typhoon did extensive damage to the farm and Bella is looking to rebuild with the help of a 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) loan to buy additional fertilizer for her pineapple plants. She has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2005 and has consistently participated in weekly fellowship meetings*.

Bella hopes that someday she will save enough to be able to purchase more farmland and generate enough income to help her children complete their studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.name: Rowilma

texts.en:
Rowilma H., age 32, and her husband, Norberto, work hard to cover their daily living expenses and to pay for their children's education.  For the past 10 years, Rowilma has been running a general store in Silang, Cavite selling meat, groceries, and prepaid credits for cell phone users through electronic loading.

Recently, customers have been seeking more variety in her store.  Rowilma would like to be able to expand the number of goods she sells and add to her existing meat and cell phone prepaid credits inventory with the help of a PHP 8,000 loan.  Rowilma has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation since 2008 and has consistently participated in weekly meetings.*  

Rowilma hopes that eventually income generated through her business will be able to fully fund her children's education.  She also dreams of expanding her business and someday purchasing a freezer to store the meat she sells. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley A., age 41, and her husband, Thomas A., a farmer and driver, age 41, are working to put their four children through high school and college.  They live in Silang, Cavite.

Shirley has been running a decorative flower and plant store as well as a Jeepney and tricycle operation business for the past five years, and hopes that the PHP 12,200 generated from these endeavors each month will continue to support her family.

Shirley has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* since 2006 and is on her eighth loan.  Shirley is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to buy more stock for her flower business and to help out with costs that arise through her Jeepney and tricycle business.  

Shirley is currently looking for a PHP 10,000 loan to help pay for additional fertilizer for her plant farm, which was damaged in a recent typhoon, and to help cover registration fees for the Jeepney and tricycle.  Shirley hopes that the additional capital will help her fully recover from the typhoon and allow her to begin expanding her flower selling business.  She hopes for a stable, happy, and peaceful life for her and her family.   

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa C. lives in the village of Bayabo East. She is 46 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business where she sells fish to people who live in her community. She has been in this business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month from her work.
